questions.question_text: A network technician is assisting a user who has relocated to a newly constructed office space. The user has no network connectivity. A cable tester was used on the port and is reporting that the pairs are open. Which of the following should be used to remedy this problem?

discussion.content: Open means there's a gap in the circuit, like a cut, or a loose wire. Only a punchdown tool can fix such physical issue.
No option can fix anything *except* the punch down tool.
no way this question would actually be on the test

comments.content: A can't be the right answer because a cable tester was used and already reported that the cables were open, thus they need to be terminated with a punchdown tool. Using a loopback adapter is testing for the connectivity, which won't work due to an open cable.
The answer should be correct as D
Yeah, it's frustrating when you don't know the tech talk!
oooouuu, so the word "...that the pairs are open." mean the cable is not terminated well?if yes, the correct answer is D

discussion.content: A should be the right answer

choices.B: Move the straight-through Ethernet cable connecting the switches to the first port on both switches.
choices.D: Add a second cable connecting the switches for redundancy and disabling STP on both switches.
choices.A: Replace the new switch with a hub to ensure Layer 1 connectivity on the new network segment.
choices.C: Connect the switches with a cable that has a TIA/EIA 586A wired connector end and a TIA/EIA 586B wired end.

questions.question_text: A technician needs to add ten additional Ethernet ports to a small office network. A new basic function switch is added. Hosts connected to the new switch are unable to see any computers on the network other than those connected to the new switch. Which of the following should the technician perform to ensure the hosts on the new switch can communicate with the existing network?

discussion.content: 568A on one end and 568B creates a cross over cable. Wouldn't have known this if it wasn't for this question and doing a little research.

The technician is tasked with setting up additional ethernet ports. In adding a new switch, i assume they are attempting to connect the new and the current switches. Crossover cables are used to connect similar devices, so in theory i believe that C is the correct answer if you are trying to pair up both switches to add the additional ethernet ports.
586A and 586B?

comments.content: So what is the meaning of a crossover? if it is not connetcting T568A with T568B. Crossover cable connects similar devices.
WHAT!!! bruh.......maybe you need study more. good luck on your test.
you are a sad, sad person
The cable that reverses all the wires is called a rollover cable. In a rollover cable, the pin order of each wire is reversed. This type of cable is less commonly used these days.

discussion.content: No they don't. Crossover cable reverses all the wires, whereas 568A and 568B differ only in 4 positions 1,2,3 and 6. You can't have a cable with 568A on one end and 568B on the other.
Agreed...cable damaged., C
It's C, because there is no power. It is likely that the device was powered over PoE, and with the cable being damaged. The switch is completely down, network included.
this question and the answers make no sense what so ever
Ok C is the answer, but why not B?

comments.content: The AP was WORKING last week and now is offline. Unless a cable was changed between then and now, then B doesn't make sense.

questions.question_text: A wireless access point that was working in a large warehouse last week is now offline. The technician observes there is no power to the device. The technician verifies PoE is working on the switchport, and then confirms the wireless access point is still not powering up. Which of the following is the MOST likely issue?
A network engineer is trying to determine where to place a firewall based on the flow of traffic. Which of the following types of documentation would assist the engineer in doing this?

comments.content: wrong. says "based on flow of traffic" can see broadcast and collision domains from logicial.

discussion.content:
physical network diagram A diagram that displays the physical layout of a
network, including placement of systems and all network cabling

questions.question_text: A user believes a work email account has been compromised. A technician discovers that an email seeming to be from the user's bank shares the same origin IP address as the last login to the email account. Which of the following types of attack is described in this scenario?

comments.content: I agree with bones. It most likely has something to do with an end user providing sensitive information to an email that was made to imitate their real bank.
are you someone from CompTIA trying to sabotage. It's obviously MIT
You are right Parti. It is a man in the middle attack.
If it was phishing the question would probably mention some sort of personal information eliciting. An IP is mentioned, as the clue, and i also think man-in-the-middle is right.

"same origin IP address as the last login to the email account."
the fake email is showing the address of the last place the user logged in at ie internet cafe or something so the MIT was used to get the address and account information for user email and hack into it....i think

discussion.content: This is a clear case of a phishing attack. The attacker obviously made it look like a legitimate email from the user's bank. User clicked links, provided credentials/personal information. Attacker gains access to the user's email account.

The problem with this question is the answer is BOTH C and D. It is a MITM Phishing attack. See here: https://terranovasecurity.com/top-examples-of-phishing-emails/. The question should have been phrased: What type of Phishing attack was this?
MITM is active eavesdropping, they are monitoring the user's email since they got access to it, which is a form of MITM.

well the mails aren't going through the hacker for it to be MITM, even if he is able to login and see them. He is phishing and at the same time he has accessed the email acc from his machine probably just to confuse us.
This is phishing guys.. don't overthink it.

Passleader has this question listed twice. The first question shows the answer as MITM, the second time it pops up it states the answer is Phishing. At least for the phishing answer there is a brief explanation given. see below:
"The attacker obviously made it look like a legitimate email from the user's bank. User clicked links, provided credentials/personal information. Attacker gains access to the user's email account.
This would make a nice use case.
They do say "types" so the one is phishing....but only 1 of them.
